content.raw:
Hello Jonathan:

We were thinking about the whole picture of releasing 1.4.12 and agreed on not to make the release at all. Here are the reasons:

* At this moment we have the same sdformat version in both, precise and trusty: 1.4.11
* precise sdformat-1.4.11 comes from OSRF or ROS repositories
* trusty sdformat-1.4.11 comes from Ubuntu

We can push into an Ubuntu released distribution only critical bug fixes (one by one), no features or other small patches. I'm afraid that our changes for 1.4.12 are not in this line. This will mean that ROS Indigo users (gazebo2 and sdformat1) won't get the latest fixes on the sdformat_1.4. In the other hand, build our own Trusty sdformat-1.4.12 and host it in OSRF and ROS repositories is an
option but implies more maintenance work (ROS is trying not to host upstream packages).

If you are looking for the moi scaling patch, two ways:

* Compile the sdformat_1.4 branch from source and/or generate your own packages
* Use gazebo4
content.html:
Hello Jonathan:

We were thinking about the whole picture of releasing 1.4.12 and agreed on not to make the release at all. Here are the reasons:

  • At this moment we have the same sdformat version in both, precise and trusty: 1.4.11
  • precise sdformat-1.4.11 comes from OSRF or ROS repositories
  • trusty sdformat-1.4.11 comes from Ubuntu

We can push into an Ubuntu released distribution only critical bug fixes (one by one), no features or other small patches. I'm afraid that our changes for 1.4.12 are not in this line. This will mean that ROS Indigo users (gazebo2 and sdformat1) won't get the latest fixes on the sdformat_1.4. In the other hand, build our own Trusty sdformat-1.4.12 and host it in OSRF and ROS repositories is an option but implies more maintenance work (ROS is trying not to host upstream packages).

If you are looking for the moi scaling patch, two ways:

  • Compile the sdformat_1.4 branch from source and/or generate your own packages
  • Use gazebo4
